reviewText: I would recommend this to any person who just doesn't like to see singers stand there like robots and have nothing in particular to say with music beyond the microphone.  In this NY production, these guys go above and beyond the call of entertainment in selecting songs that bring out their individual ranges of voice, their personalities, versatile talents, humor and intelligence.  They are quite gifted and remarkable actors, working well solo or together.  A couple of selections brought tears to my eyes because the songs were either absolutely meaningful, like "Make Them Hear You" by Rodrick Dixon, or the hilarious "Twisted" by James Young, or "Minnie the Moocher" by Victor Trent Cook, or "Today I Sing the Blues" by all three guys.  I got to see them in concert in Baltimore -- and I have to be honest that the selections were not half as good, in my estimation, as those on this DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I purchased the audio CD to this concert some time ago and was advised to get the DVD. I am entralled by the performances. Its absolutely splendid especially the performances of the Jazz related pieces in the concert.Bravo

reviewText: Dixon Trent and Young are alright. Trent, I am familiar with from the Leiber and Stoller show. The other guys are new to me. But each one holds his own. It took me three tries and eight months to order this. I am finally glad to get it. And it is a delight. Something else to turn my children on to.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Mssrs. Cook, Dixon and Young are simply amazing. I found this DVD to try to show my predominately African-American humanities class that classical music wasn't "white" any more than jazz, blues and swing were "black" genres. What I got was so much more. This is a fabulous DVD and so eclectic, containing everything from "dirty" jazz to Mozart to gospel to Duke Ellington. What a joy!And while Victor Trent Cook's "Minne the Moocher" is a showstopper, my favorite performance was "Make Them Hear You," a cry for justice that moved me to tears. How wonderful!
Title: N/A

reviewText: What a delightful, original, high quality (both sound and video) performance.  Not to be missed, it will appeal to listeners (watchers) of all age groups.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I use Three Mo Tenors in my Humanities class to introduce Opera and to my Contemorary Fine Arts classes to demonstrate diversity. It begins with an aria getting the 'Three Tenors' treatment which morphs into various exciting forms of more accessible music like soul, MoTown, gospel, jazz, and blues. These guys are the real deal. Students realize it and generally accept the different forms of music that are so masterfully executed. There is even a touching rendition of "Nothing's Going to Harm You" from Sweeney Todd. The secret is to prepare the students to be bored by Opera so that you let them discover the surprize.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was simply blown away.  Performing in one concert the many different genres of music was phenominal.  I have never heard of anyone doing this until The Three Mo' Tenors.I own the dvd and bought several as gifts.
